titleStmt.title:
Van──' House Built from the ruines of
Whitehall yt was burnt

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: written 1703
In Times of old, when Time was young
And Poets their own Verses sung
A verse could draw a stone or Beam
That now woul'd overload a Team.
Lead 'em a Dance of many a Mile,
Then rear 'em to a goodly Pile.
Each number had its different power;
Heroick Strains could build a Tower;
Sonnets or Elegies to Chloris
Might raise a house about two Storyes;
A Lyrick Ode would Slate: a Catch
Would Tile; an Epigram would Thatch.
But to their own & landlords cost,
Now Poets feel this Art is lost:
Not one of all our tunefull Throng
Can raise a Lodging for a Song.
For Iove consider'd well the Case,
Observ'd they grew a numerous Race,
And should they Build as fast as writ
Twould ruin Undertakers quite.
This evil therefore to prevent,
He wisely changed their Element:
On Earth, the God of Wealth was made
Sole Patron of the building Trade,
Leaving the witts the spacious air,
With License to build Castles there:
And tis conceivd their old Pretence
To lodge in Garrets comes from thence.
Premising thus in Modern way
The better half wee had to say;
Sing Muse the House of Poet Van
In higher strain then wee began.
Van (for 'tis fit ye Reader know it)
Is both a Herald and a Poet
No wonder then if nicely skilld,
In both Capacityes to Build.
As Herald, he can in a Day
Repair a House gone to Decay,
Or by Atchivement, Arms, Device,
Erect a new one in a trice.
And as a Poet, he has skill.
To build in Speculation still.
But this would stand in little Stead,
Van wanted where to lay his Head.
Great Iove, he cry'd the art restore
To build by Verse as heretofore,
And make my Muse the Architect;
What Palaces shall wee erect!
No Longer shall forsaken Thames
Lament his old Whitehall in Flames
A Pile shall from it's ashes rise
Fitt to invade, or prop the Skyes
Iove smil'd and like a gentle God
Consenting wth the usual Nod,
Told Van he knew his Talent best.
And left the choice to his own breast.
So Van resolv'd to writ a Farce
But well perceiving Witt was scarce,
With Cunning that Defect supplyes,
Takes a French Play as lawfull Prize,
Steals thence his Plot & every Ioke,
Not once suspecting Iove would smoke,
And (like a wag) satt down to write,
Wou'd whisper to himself. A Bite──
Then from this motly mingled stile
Proceeded to erect his Pile:
So men of old to gain renown did
Build Babel with their Tongues confounded
Iove saw the Cheat but thought it best
To turn the matter to a Iest;
Down from Olympus Top he slides
Laughing as if he'd burst his Sides
Ay, thought the God are these your Tricks?
Why then, Old Plays, deserve Old Bricks
And since you're sparing of \add·yr\ Stuff,
Your building shall be smal enuff.
He spake, and grudging lent his Ayd;
Th'experienc'd Bricks that knew their Trade
(As being Bricks at Second Hand)
Now move, and now in order stand.
The building as the Poet writt,
Rose in proportion to his witt:
And first the Prologue built a Wall
So wide as to encompass all.
The scene (a Wood) produc't no more
Then a few scrubby Trees before.
The Plot as yet lay deep, and so
A Cellar next was dug below:
But this a work so hard was found
Two Acts it cost him under-ground
Two other Acts wee may presume,
Were spent in building each a room;
Thus far advanc't, \erasure\·he made a shift
To raise a Roof with Act the Fift.
The Epilogue behind did frame
A place not decent here to name.──
Now Poets from all quarters ran
To see the House of Brother Van:
Look't high & low, walk't often round
But no such House was to be found;
One ask'd the Watermen hard by
Where may the Poets Palace ly?
Another of the Thames enquires,
If he has seen its guilded Spires?
At length they in the Rubbish spy
Somewhat resembling a Goose Pye;
Thither in hast ye Poets throng
And gaze in silent wonder Long,
Til one in Raptures thus began
To praise the House and Builder Van.
Thrice happy Poet, who may trail
Thy House about thee like a Snail;
Or harnest to a Nag at ease
Take journyes in it like a Chaise;
Or in a Boat when e're thou wilt
Canst make it serve \add·thee\ for a Tilt.
Capacious House! 'tis own'd by all
Thou'rt well contriv'd tho' thou art smal:
For ev'ry witt in Britains Isle
May lodge within thy spacious Pile.
Like Bacchus Thou, as Poets feign
Thy mother burnt art born again;
Born like a Phenix from the Flame
But neither Bulk, nor Shape the same:
As Animals of largest size
Corrupt to Maggots, worms, and Flyes.
A Type of Modern witt and Style
The Rubbish of an ancient Pile.
So Chymists boast, they have a Power
From the dead ashes of a Flower
Some faint resemblance to produce,
But not the Vertue tast or juyce.
So modern Rimers wisely blast
The Poetry of Ages past,
Which after the have overthrown,
They from it's ruines build their own.
